instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
I got this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, which have looping 5V 0.3A on the charger.
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> shows a pulsing heat signature on both charging ports. While <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> is shorting. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> shows 0.5Vdc.

I don't see any liquid damage on the board itself, only the bottom of the battery sensors flipped red.
I just got the chips today. Shall I replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> first? If there is something else, I should check first to prevent shorting the replaced chip. Avoiding wasting chips, ubelievable how expensive these chips are for new macs?

I can't detect any shorts on the major coils, CDxxx fuses, or bigger filtering caps.

Thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Change the chip.
Once the chip is removed, check if short has gone.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
No short on chip removal replaced it and also no short. Seems like <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> was shorting internally.
Also, no more heat signatures on it, but still loops at 5V.

The only heat signature I detect is <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>/bios?, pulsing to +/- 10*C

Also noticed that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> leg of <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> is dissolved. Removed the <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> while testing, its filtering cap should not affect it right?

Where to next?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Both USB ports have the same behaviour?

If all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present, machine should enter DFU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes both USB-c loops, although the one closer to the screen (top one) loops every 15 sec, compared to the bottom one every 5 sec. Not sure which one is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. Suspecting the bottom one is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> USB-C port

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.85V
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - Loops 0.75V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE - Loops 0.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE_SOC_TSADC_RC</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE_SOC_FMON_RC</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.21V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE_SOC_PLLSOC_F</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE_SOC_PLLCPU_F</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.20V
PP1V2_AWAKE_SOC_PCIEREFBUF_F - Loops 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE_SOC_PCIEPLL_F</SIGNAL> - Loops 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - Loops 3.24V

<SIGNAL>SOC_BLUE_AWAKE</SIGNAL> - 0.01V - Expected?

SLP2SR I don't have those lines, Do you mean <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SXX</SIGNAL> lines? <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0</SIGNAL>/S3 lines does not have any voltage on them

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Use boardview to identify each USB port and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> pair.
Compare diode mode to ground on LDO rails of both chips.
Check for short on all big coils (secondary power supplies).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Top USB-C - <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> - XA - Loops every 15 sec
Bottom USB-C - <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> - XB- Loops every 5 sec - the one which got replaced

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.49Vdc
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XB_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 0.52Vdc
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.32Vdc

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.51Vdc
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_XA_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 0.51Vdc
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.32Vdc

Let me know if I missed <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> LDO line, these seems to be the ones around them.

Went through all bigger filtering caps, coils as well as fuses. No short to be seen. Only close proximity to the CPU coils and caps shows a low resistance.

Found PP1V8 SLP2SR  line, which seems ok at 1.8V

Also noticed <SIGNAL>UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(B)_FAULT_L to jump 0V->0.15V when it loops 5v->0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
No liquid, but how the problem appeared?
Any liquid sign on audio board, touch ID, or touchbar?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Went inch by inch under a microscope, the only liquid sign is around the bottom of the battery where the trackpad is. No other liquid signs. Apparently water bottle leaked in a backpack.
I'm testing on a bench with a USB-C port attached only

Also noticed that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> leg of <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> is dissolved. Removed the <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> while testing, its filtering cap should not affect it right?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> too.
Once removed, check if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> arrives to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> pads.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.30V / 0.42Vdc on all three pads with removed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. looks normal right? Shall I resolder new <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>. This is the last one I have. 

How do you reball <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, Is it worth it? I have seen some stencils available.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: Use solder paste, is the fastest way.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Thanks for the tip. So clean with fresh solder and wick, apply solder paste on stencil and hot air until it creates balls? Do you have a video you came across to see?

How is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> voltage/resistance sounds like? Shall I solder a new chip and try?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> readings look good.

Use minimum air flow, when create the balls.
I recommend you to remove the nozzle from hot-air station also.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: I still need a stencil right?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Of course.
I don't know if you can find and use an universal model.
Like the ones for mobile phones repair, with several layouts in the same sheet.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, still stuck on 5V 0.25A. With a difference that both USB ports loop every 15 sec.

I am out of ideas. Any suggestions?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: A strange thing happened, I have soldered <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with the one which was there previously and now 5V 0.2A stays stable with no looping on both ports. Does that mean anything? Is it worth fighting with this case?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: Try DFU now...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: No luck with DFU mode, tried multiple cables.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Stuck on 5V looping on both ports, with pulsing heat on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
threads.message: You may have a bad T2 then...
